title: Susac Syndrome
icd10: ** H35.89 (Other specified retinal disorders -- branch retinal artery occlusion component)
H93.09 (Unspecified degenerative and vascular disorders of ear -- sensorineural hearing loss component)
scope: ** Diagnosis, immunotherapy, and long-term monitoring of Susac syndrome -- an autoimmune endotheliopathy affecting small vessels of the brain, retina, and cochlea. Covers the classic clinical triad (encephalopathy with corpus callosum lesions, branch retinal artery occlusion, sensorineural hearing loss), diagnostic workup including MRI with characteristic "snowball" corpus callosum lesions, fluorescein angiography, audiometry, CSF analysis, and immunotherapy (IVIG, high-dose corticosteroids, plasma exchange, and long-term immunosuppression with mycophenolate mofetil, azathioprine, or rituximab). Includes differentiation from multiple sclerosis, CNS vasculitis, ADEM, and other autoimmune encephalopathies. Not all patients present with the complete triad simultaneously; a high index of suspicion is required. For primary CNS vasculitis, use "CNS Vasculitis (PACNS)" template. For autoimmune encephalitis with antibody-mediated mechanisms, use "Autoimmune Encephalitis" template. For MS, use "MS - New Diagnosis" template.

Essential/First-line.target: Rule out hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus; CT is often normal early in Susac syndrome

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.target: PATHOGNOMONIC: "Snowball" lesions in central fibers of corpus callosum (best seen on sagittal T2/FLAIR and DWI); multifocal white matter T2/FLAIR hyperintensities in deep gray matter, periventricular white matter, posterior fossa, and internal capsule; leptomeningeal enhancement; callosal lesions with central "hole" pattern (icicle lesions); DWI restriction in acute lesions
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Pacemaker; metallic implants; GFR <30 for gadolinium

Essential/First-line.target: DIAGNOSTIC: Branch retinal artery occlusion (BRAO); arteriolar wall hyperfluorescence (pathognomonic -- represents endothelial damage); non-filling of arteriolar segments; retinal capillary leakage; multiple arterial branch occlusions often bilateral; abnormal even without visual symptoms
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Fluorescein allergy; severe renal impairment (relative); pregnancy (relative)

Essential/First-line.target: Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) predominantly low and mid-frequency (unlike presbycusis which is high-frequency); unilateral or bilateral; fluctuating; progressive to severe/profound
Cotton-wool spots; Hollenhorst plaques (rare); arteriolar wall changes; retinal whitening from BRAO; multiple branch artery territory infarcts
Baseline; arrhythmia screen; cardiac source of emboli in differential
Exclude pulmonary pathology; mediastinal lymphadenopathy (sarcoidosis differential)

Extended.item: MRI brain with sagittal FLAIR and DWI (dedicated Susac protocol) (CPT 70553)
Extended.target: Sagittal FLAIR is critical: central callosal "snowball" lesions (3-7 mm round lesions in central corpus callosum fibers); "icicle" or "spoke" lesions hanging from inferior surface of corpus callosum; leptomeningeal enhancement; deep gray matter lesions (thalamus, basal ganglia); cerebellar lesions; DWI restriction indicates acute/active disease
Retinal nerve fiber layer thinning; inner retinal layer loss from ischemia; macular edema; arteriolar wall changes; serial OCT monitors for disease progression and treatment response
Scotomas corresponding to BRAO territories; reveals subclinical retinal ischemia
Absent or reduced emissions indicating outer hair cell damage; cochlear ischemia pattern; complements audiometry
Prolonged latencies or absent waves; helps differentiate cochlear (Susac) from retrocochlear (acoustic neuroma) pathology
Typically normal in Susac syndrome (small vessel disease below MRA resolution); helps exclude large vessel vasculitis or RCVS

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute immunosuppression for confirmed or strongly suspected Susac syndrome; reduces endothelial inflammation and prevents further ischemic injury to brain, retina, and cochlea

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily for 3-5 days; infuse over 1-2 hours; begin upon strong clinical suspicion; cornerstone of acute management along with IVIG

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (neuroimmunology specialist) for Susac syndrome diagnosis confirmation, immunotherapy initiation, and long-term management
Ophthalmology (retinal specialist) for fluorescein angiography, fundoscopic examination, OCT, and serial retinal monitoring; essential for diagnosis and treatment monitoring
Otolaryngology/Audiology for comprehensive audiometry, DPOAE, ABR, hearing aid fitting, and cochlear implant evaluation if severe/profound SNHL
Rheumatology for exclusion of systemic autoimmune disease (SLE, antiphospholipid syndrome) and co-management of immunosuppressive therapy
Neuroradiology for MRI interpretation with Susac protocol (sagittal FLAIR corpus callosum lesion characterization) and serial imaging comparison
Infectious disease for exclusion of infectious etiologies (syphilis, VZV, TB) mimicking Susac triad and infection management during immunosuppression
Hematology if thrombotic microangiopathy suspected (TTP/HUS differential) or for plasma exchange management
Physical therapy for motor rehabilitation, gait training, balance assessment, and fall prevention given potential cerebellar and deep gray matter involvement
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, cognitive rehabilitation, and adaptive strategies for visual and hearing impairment
Speech-language pathology for communication strategies (hearing loss), swallowing evaluation if brainstem involvement, and cognitive-linguistic therapy
Neuropsychology for formal cognitive assessment given cognitive decline and encephalopathy as core features; serial monitoring to track treatment response
Social work for insurance navigation (IVIG is costly), disability resources, and family support during prolonged treatment
Endocrinology for steroid-induced diabetes management if persistent hyperglycemia during corticosteroid therapy
Low vision rehabilitation services for patients with permanent visual field deficits from BRAO
Cochlear implant evaluation (otology/neurotology) for severe bilateral sensorineural hearing loss not responding to treatment and not adequately aided

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for new or worsening visual loss (scotomas, blurred vision, visual field cuts), sudden hearing loss, new headache, confusion, or weakness -- these indicate disease relapse with new BRAO or CNS lesion
Do not stop corticosteroids abruptly -- abrupt cessation causes adrenal crisis and disease flare; taper must be supervised by neurology
Report signs of infection promptly (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria, rash, mouth sores) while on immunosuppressive therapy, as infection risk is significantly increased
Avoid live vaccines during immunosuppressive therapy (MMR, varicella, zoster live, yellow fever, intranasal influenza); inform all healthcare providers of immunosuppressed status
Do not drive until cleared by neurology and ophthalmology due to risk of seizures, cognitive impairment, and visual field deficits from BRAO
Expect prolonged treatment course (minimum 2 years, often longer); adherence to monthly IVIG and daily immunosuppressant is essential to prevent relapse and cumulative organ damage
Avoid pregnancy during mycophenolate therapy; discuss contraception with neurology and OB/GYN before starting treatment
Wear medical alert bracelet identifying immunosuppressed status and Susac syndrome diagnosis
Report any new visual symptoms (floaters, scotomas, field cuts), hearing changes (new loss, tinnitus, fullness), or cognitive difficulties between visits, as these indicate subclinical relapse
Attend all scheduled follow-up appointments including MRI surveillance, fluorescein angiography, audiometry, and laboratory monitoring
Use assistive devices for hearing loss (hearing aids, captioning, FM systems) and visual impairment (magnifiers, contrast enhancement) to maintain function and safety
Avoid excessive sun exposure while on immunosuppressive therapy due to increased skin cancer risk; use sunscreen SPF 30+

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Stop smoking to reduce microvascular disease risk and improve treatment response; smoking worsens endothelial dysfunction
Blood pressure target <140/90 mmHg (lower if tolerated) to reduce microvascular risk and prevent further ischemic injury
Low-sodium diet to manage steroid-induced fluid retention and hypertension
Regular weight-bearing exercise as tolerated to maintain bone density during prolonged corticosteroid therapy; target 150 min/week of moderate activity
Adequate hydration (minimum 2L/day) to reduce thrombotic risk and support renal function during IVIG therapy
Pneumococcal (PCV20) and annual influenza vaccination (inactivated only) before or during immunosuppression when possible; avoid live vaccines
Home safety evaluation to address fall hazards given potential visual field deficits, hearing loss, balance impairment, and cognitive dysfunction
Cognitive stimulation activities (reading, puzzles, social engagement) to support cognitive recovery alongside formal rehabilitation
Stress management and psychological support given multi-organ disease with significant functional impact on daily life; referral to support groups
Regular ophthalmologic monitoring even during remission to detect subclinical retinal artery occlusions before permanent visual loss occurs

differential.features: White matter lesions BUT: callosal lesions in MS are periventricular (Dawson fingers at calloso-septal interface) NOT central corpus callosum "snowball" lesions; no BRAO; no low-frequency SNHL; CSF shows prominent oligoclonal bands; typical MS relapsing pattern
differential.tests: MRI (Dawson fingers vs. central callosal snowballs); fluorescein angiography (normal in MS); audiometry (normal in MS); CSF OCBs (strong positive in MS, weak/absent in Susac)

differential.features: Subacute progressive course; multifocal infarcts in multiple vascular territories; CSF shows significant lymphocytic pleocytosis (WBC 10-150) with elevated protein; angiographic beading; no BRAO pattern; no characteristic low-frequency SNHL
differential.tests: CSF (higher pleocytosis in PACNS); conventional angiography (abnormal in PACNS, normal in Susac); fluorescein angiography (BRAO pattern in Susac, not PACNS); MRI (central callosal snowballs absent in PACNS); brain biopsy (transmural vasculitis in PACNS vs. endotheliopathy in Susac)

differential.features: Monophasic course; often post-infectious or post-vaccination; large, poorly marginated white matter lesions; deep gray matter involvement; no BRAO; no SNHL; pediatric predominance
differential.tests: MRI (large fluffy lesions vs. small snowball callosal lesions); fluorescein angiography (normal in ADEM); audiometry (normal in ADEM); CSF (similar mild pleocytosis but no BRAO)

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies (CN VII, VIII); basilar leptomeningeal enhancement; hypothalamic involvement; hilar lymphadenopathy; elevated ACE; granulomatous inflammation on biopsy
differential.tests: ACE level (serum and CSF); chest CT (bilateral hilar adenopathy); biopsy (non-caseating granulomas); FDG-PET; no central callosal snowball lesions; FA shows retinal periphlebitis (not arteriolar occlusion)

differential.features: Recurrent arterial/venous thrombosis; pregnancy losses; livedo reticularis; retinal vascular occlusion can occur BUT central retinal artery or vein, not typically branch arteriolar pattern; no central callosal snowball lesions
differential.tests: Anticardiolipin, anti-beta2-glycoprotein I, lupus anticoagulant (confirmed on repeat 12 weeks apart); MRI pattern differs; no characteristic low-frequency SNHL

differential.features: Interstitial keratitis (NOT retinal artery occlusion) + vestibuloacoustic dysfunction; systemic vasculitis (aortitis); no characteristic callosal lesions on MRI; audiovestibular symptoms more vestibular-predominant
differential.tests: Slit-lamp examination (interstitial keratitis in Cogan, absent in Susac); fluorescein angiography (BRAO in Susac, not Cogan); MRI (no callosal snowballs in Cogan); CT aorta (aortitis in Cogan)

differential.features: History of zoster; retinal necrosis (NOT typical BRAO pattern); encephalopathy with vasculopathy; CSF pleocytosis with VZV antibodies; responds to acyclovir
differential.tests: CSF VZV PCR and VZV IgG (positive in VZV vasculopathy); MRI pattern (not central callosal snowballs); fluorescein angiography (retinal necrosis pattern vs. BRAO); response to acyclovir (no response in Susac)

differential.features: Meningovascular syphilis can cause encephalopathy, hearing loss, and retinal disease (mimics complete triad); Argyll Robertson pupils; positive syphilis serology
differential.tests: RPR/VDRL; CSF VDRL; FTA-ABS; MRI pattern differs (no central callosal snowballs); responds to IV penicillin

differential.features: Central or branch retinal artery occlusion from cardiac emboli (atrial fibrillation, endocarditis, PFO); no encephalopathy unless concurrent stroke; no SNHL; Hollenhorst plaques on fundoscopy
differential.tests: Echocardiogram (embolic source); cardiac monitoring (atrial fibrillation); FA (single territory vs. multifocal arteriolar occlusions in Susac); no callosal snowballs; no hearing loss

differential.features: Bilateral panuveitis with exudative retinal detachments; hearing loss; meningismus; vitiligo, poliosis; CSF pleocytosis; uveal (choroidal) not arteriolar disease
differential.tests: Fluorescein angiography (choroidal pattern in VKH vs. arteriolar occlusion in Susac); OCT (subretinal fluid in VKH); skin findings (vitiligo/poliosis in VKH); MRI (no callosal snowballs in VKH)

differential.features: Retinal vasculitis with peripheral retinal ischemia; predominantly venous involvement (periphlebitis); vitreous hemorrhage; young males; no CNS involvement; no SNHL
differential.tests: Fluorescein angiography (periphlebitis and peripheral ischemia in Eales vs. arteriolar BRAO in Susac); MRI brain (normal in Eales); audiometry (normal in Eales); no encephalopathy

differential.features: Recurrent subcortical strokes; migraine with aura; progressive cognitive decline; white matter disease; temporal pole and external capsule involvement; autosomal dominant; NOTCH3 mutation
differential.tests: Genetic testing (NOTCH3 mutation); MRI (anterior temporal and external capsule involvement characteristic of CADASIL); no BRAO; no SNHL; skin biopsy (GOM deposits); family history

differential.features: Oral and genital ulcers; uveitis (not BRAO); brainstem syndrome; venous sinus thrombosis; pathergy; HLA-B51 associated
differential.tests: HLA-B51; clinical criteria (oral ulcers, genital ulcers, pathergy); slit-lamp (uveitis not BRAO); MRI pattern (brainstem predilection in neuro-Behcet); no callosal snowballs

monitoring.item: Neurologic examination (mental status, cranial nerves, motor, sensory, coordination)
monitoring.frequency: Q4-6h (ICU); Q8-12h (floor)
monitoring.action: If worsening: urgent MRI; escalate immunotherapy; initiate PLEX if on steroids + IVIG; ICU transfer

monitoring.item: Visual acuity and confrontational visual fields
monitoring.frequency: Daily; Q8h if actively declining
monitoring.action: New scotoma or acuity loss: urgent fluorescein angiography; escalate treatment; ophthalmology reassessment

monitoring.item: Hearing assessment (bedside; whispered voice, tuning fork)
monitoring.frequency: Daily
monitoring.action: New or worsening hearing loss: urgent audiometry; escalate treatment; audiology reassessment

monitoring.frequency: Q6h during IV methylprednisolone; QID during oral prednisone
monitoring.action: Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consult if persistent >250 mg/dL

monitoring.frequency: Q1h (ICU); Q4h (floor)
monitoring.action: Treat hypertension; avoid excessive lowering in setting of CNS ischemia

monitoring.frequency: Q4h; continuous in ICU
monitoring.action: Fever workup (blood/urine cultures); distinguish infection from IVIG reaction

monitoring.frequency: Daily during acute phase; q48h after stabilization
monitoring.action: Hold immunosuppression if critically low; evaluate for alternative diagnosis if unexpected cytopenias

monitoring.frequency: Daily; more frequently during IVIG and PLEX
monitoring.action: Adjust IVIG infusion rate; hold if Cr rising; electrolyte repletion

monitoring.frequency: Q48-72h during acute treatment
monitoring.action: Dose adjustment or hold hepatotoxic medications

monitoring.frequency: Continuous observation; EEG if seizures or altered consciousness
monitoring.action: Escalate ASMs per Section 3A; continuous EEG if subclinical seizures suspected

monitoring.frequency: Q15min first hour; Q30-60min subsequent
monitoring.action: Slow or stop infusion for reaction; premedicate for subsequent infusions; switch IVIG product if recurrent reactions

monitoring.frequency: Daily
monitoring.action: Adjust IV fluids; diuretics if fluid overload

monitoring.frequency: Monthly x 6 months; then q3 months x 2 years; then q6 months
monitoring.action: If new deficits or worsening: urgent MRI + FA + audiometry; reassess treatment; evaluate for relapse

monitoring.item: MRI brain with sagittal FLAIR (Susac protocol)
monitoring.frequency: 3 months post-induction; then q6 months x 2 years; then annually x 3 years
monitoring.action: New lesions (especially DWI-restricting): relapse; escalate treatment; increase IVIG frequency; add or switch immunosuppressant

monitoring.frequency: 3 months post-induction; then q6 months x 2 years; then annually
monitoring.action: New BRAO or arteriolar wall changes: subclinical relapse; escalate treatment even if asymptomatic

monitoring.frequency: 3 months post-induction; then q6 months x 2 years; then annually
monitoring.action: New hearing loss or worsening thresholds: relapse; escalate treatment; hearing aid adjustment or cochlear implant evaluation

monitoring.frequency: Q6 months x 2 years; then annually
monitoring.action: Progressive thinning: ongoing subclinical retinal ischemia; correlate with FA; adjust treatment

monitoring.frequency: Monthly during first 3 months on immunosuppressant; then q3 months
monitoring.action: Hold or reduce immunosuppression; dose adjust; evaluate for alternative agent

monitoring.frequency: Monthly x 3 months on mycophenolate/azathioprine; then q3 months
monitoring.action: Dose reduction or switch agent; hepatology referral if persistent

monitoring.frequency: Before each IVIG infusion; q3 months
monitoring.action: Adjust IVIG infusion rate; nephrology referral if declining GFR

monitoring.frequency: Q3-6 months during maintenance IVIG
monitoring.action: Adjust IVIG dose or frequency; subtherapeutic levels contribute to relapse

monitoring.frequency: Q3-6 months
monitoring.action: Rising markers: assess for disease activity vs. infection; clinical correlation required

monitoring.frequency: Baseline if steroids >3 months; repeat q1-2 years
monitoring.action: Bisphosphonate therapy; calcium/vitamin D optimization; endocrine referral

monitoring.frequency: Q3 months during steroid therapy
monitoring.action: Adjust diabetes medications; dietary counseling; endocrine referral

monitoring.frequency: Once before starting azathioprine
monitoring.action: Dose reduce (intermediate) or avoid (deficient) azathioprine

monitoring.frequency: Baseline (when stable); 6 months; 12 months; then annually
monitoring.action: Guide cognitive rehabilitation; adjust treatment; inform return-to-work planning

monitoring.frequency: Q6 months x 2 years; then annually
monitoring.action: New scotomas: correlate with FA; indicates subclinical BRAO

monitoring.frequency: Q3-6 months if on rituximab
monitoring.action: Immunoglobulin replacement if recurrent infections with hypogammaglobulinemia

monitoring.frequency: Q3 months if on rituximab
monitoring.action: Repopulating B-cells trigger relapse; guide re-dosing timing

monitoring.frequency: Each visit
monitoring.action: Adjust antihypertensive therapy; dietary counseling

disposition.criteria: Stable or improving neurologic examination, visual acuity, and hearing; no new lesions on MRI; tolerating oral medications; oral prednisone taper established; outpatient IVIG infusions arranged; follow-up with neurology and ophthalmology within 1-2 weeks; caregiver education completed; no active seizures; adequate home support; assistive devices (hearing aids, magnifiers) addressed

New presentation with suspected Susac syndrome requiring urgent workup (MRI, FA, audiometry, LP); initiation of IV methylprednisolone + IVIG; new visual loss or hearing loss; new neurologic deficits; encephalopathy requiring monitoring; seizures requiring medication adjustment; diagnostic uncertainty requiring expedited evaluation

Severe encephalopathy (GCS <12); status epilepticus; rapid neurologic deterioration despite treatment; plasma exchange requiring hemodynamic monitoring; severe IVIG reactions; post-brain biopsy monitoring; acute clinical deterioration with multiorgan involvement; need for continuous EEG monitoring

Fluorescein angiography or retinal specialist not available; neuroimmunology specialist not available; plasma exchange not available; MRI with dedicated Susac protocol not available; cochlear implant evaluation needed

Medically stable; significant functional deficits from encephalopathy, visual loss, hearing loss, or motor deficits requiring intensive therapy; unable to safely return home; expected to benefit from structured rehabilitation program incorporating cognitive, visual, and auditory rehabilitation

All patients: neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks post-discharge; ophthalmology for serial FA and OCT; audiology for serial audiometry; IVIG infusion center arrangements; rheumatology co-management; neuropsychology referral; rehabilitation services; laboratory monitoring per protocol

New or worsening visual loss (new BRAO); new or worsening hearing loss; new neurologic deficits or cognitive decline; breakthrough seizures; signs of treatment complication (infection, IVIG reaction, renal dysfunction); suspected disease relapse on imaging
